posts.name: Alder St. Food Cart Pod
posts.note: Alder St. Food Cart Pod is the largest downtown collection of Portland’s famed food carts is located between Southwest Alder and Washington streets, from Southwest Ninth to Southwest Tenth avenues. Most carts are open extended lunch hours on weekday afternoons. A few carts have limited sidewalk seating; Director Park is nearby. It's the home of spots like The Dump Truck, the Grilled Cheese Grill, Bing Mi Crepes, and, probably most notably, Nong’s Khao Man Gai.

posts.name: Ate-Oh-Ate
posts.note: Ate-Oh-Ate has counter-service Hawaiian restaurant serving plate lunches, poke, and shave ice, plus cocktails. I ordered the Kahlua Pig with a side macaroni salad and two scoops of rice along with a Spam Musubi which is spam sushi made with spam, rice, and egg wrapped in seaweed. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bamboo Sushi
posts.note: Bamboo Sushi is from their website, 'driven by a deep commitment to environmental and social change; we set out to make an impact in this world. Setting a new standard for restaurants, we combine the values and guidelines of multiple international organizations to ensure every plate we serve reflects our deep dedication to sustainability. Bamboo Sushi became the world’s first restaurant to know their carbon footprint down to the menu item.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bing Mi Crepes
posts.note: Bing Mi Crepes is a food truck dispensing Chinese crepes filled with egg, pickled vegetables, and herbs. The only item they make is the Jian Bing which is a giant crepe that is filled with egg, black bean sauce, and chili paste, plus herbs, pickled vegetables, and crispy wonton crackers. Add even more sweet-sour-savory notes with the addition of the optional Hoisin sauce and sausage if you so desire, which I did. Their medium sauce had the right amount of heat for me.

posts.name: Blue Star Donuts
posts.note: Blue Star Donuts is an upmarket brioche-donut bakery features creative flavors and organic, locally sourced ingredients. Blue Star Donuts makes the best apple fritters I have ever eaten, and I'm in my mid 50's. I've even gone back a second or third, or more times their donuts rock. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bollywood Theater
posts.note: Bollywood Theater is a casual stop for Indian street-food classics, with old Bollywood films showing on a wall. NOTEThey have two locations.

posts.name: Broder Cafe
posts.note: Broder Cafe serves breakfast dishes, and Bloody Marys are especially popular at this small, simple Scandinavian eatery. NOTE They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bunk Sandwiches
posts.note: Bunk's signature sandwiches - such as the Pork Belly Cubano, the Meatball Parmigiana Hero, and the Pulled Pork with Apple Cabbage Slaw - have garnered national media attention. I had to order the Pork Belly Cubano with ham, pork belly, and pork shoulder roast, swiss cheese, mustard, and pickles from their food truck at XOXO Festival. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Burgerville
posts.note: Burgerville is a fast-food chain using local, sustainable ingredients in its burgers, salads, and shakes. If you order their egg and cheese breakfast sandwich, you can get with bacon, ham, or sausage along with a burger. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bushel and Peck Bakeshop
posts.add1: 3907 NE Martin Luther King Jr Blvd
posts.note: Bushel and Peck Bakeshop is a bakery and coffeehouse prepping sandwiches along with sweet-savory pastries in a mod, farmhouse-like space. Don’t forget to order one of their breakfast sandwiches.

posts.name: Canard
posts.note: From the Eater website about Canard, 'The look of Gabriel Rucker’s latest PDX project feels very bistro-du-jour: a curving bar where rows of wine glasses dangle in tight rows like chimes, gilded mirrors, the walls a chic shade of butterscotch. The food may careen into French territory here and there, but this is really exuberant, zigzagging American cooking. Just have it: oeufs en mayonnaise, scented with smoked maple, bacon, and roasted garlic and beaded with trout roe; sliders dubbed “steam burgers,” the beef patty revved with French onion soup; and the already-famous duck stack, a mound of pancakes pummeled with duck gravy, Tabasco onions, a runny duck egg, and, to add excess to overindulgence, optional seared foie gras on top. This all tastes way more of restrained balance than seems possible. Downing a last few drops of Champagne, I bounced out the door humming with a single thought: That was fun.' According to J. Kenji López-Alt, you need to order the steamed burgers.
posts.rcmmnd: J. Kenji López-Alt and Eater's 18 Best New Restaurants in America - 2018

posts.name: Cartopia
posts.note: Cartopia is a group of food carts known as a 'pod' which features a variety of fare from lunch through late-night. They have a covered, heated seating area, and most carts are lively late at night, staying open until midnight Tuesday-Thursday and until 3 a.m. Friday and Saturday.

posts.name: Chicken and Guns
posts.note: Chicken and Guns serves Oak Fired Latin Chicken. They only use naturally raised chickens from Scratch Farms in Canby, OR. All ingredients are sourced locally when possible. Their chicken and sides are great and would eat there again.

posts.name: Coava Coffee Roasters
posts.note: Coava Coffee Roasters serves a variety of quality coffee beverages and light bites at this industrial-chic space. From their website, 'Coava is committed to long term, sustainable partnerships with coffee producers. As far as we’re concerned, obtaining high scoring green coffee is only the beginning. We are dedicated to a sourcing model that is not only good for farmers but is good for the industry as a whole.'

posts.name: Coco Donuts
posts.note: Coco Donuts is a low-key bakeshop doling out homemade glazed, twist, and jelly donuts, along with fritters, bars, and coffee. From their website, 'Some businesses sell a product; Coco Donuts sells an experience. The Coco Donuts Experience combines two high-quality commodities: donuts and coffee. Coco Donuts is the only donut shop in Portland crafting both quality donuts and house-roasted coffee.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Cup and Bar
posts.add1: 118 NE Martin Luther King Jr Blvd
posts.note: Ranger Chocolate Co. serves inventive light dishes served with Trailhead Coffee Roasters and Ranger Chocolate Company products. From teh Portland Eater website, 'This industrial chocolate-coffee tasting room normally serves its drinking chocolate flight-style, but the shop is currently only doing serving hot chocolates and mochas. Still, the chocolate drinks are still exceptional, all made with a special chocolate syrup that’s made in-house using Ranger Chocolate. Ranger Chocalte Co. also currently has a special vegan white chocolate that’s being used in the candy cane white chocolate mocha.'

posts.name: Danwei Canting
posts.note: Danwei Canting is a Chinese dumplings, noodles, and street-inspired small plates, plus cocktails, in industrial-chic digs. From their website,'Inspired by our lives in and travels to the Middle Kingdom, DĀNWÈI CĀNTĪNG (the Work Unit Restaurant) is a snapshot of the food and energy of Beijing. Our goal is to share Chinese home-style dishes (JIĀCHÁNG CÀI) with the people of Portland, using great technique and fresh local ingredients. Our name derives from the place where workers in China, up until the mid-1990s, would eat their meals. Since the members of the work unit came from all over China, the chef needed to be able to not only prepare local dishes but regional specialties as well. Our chef has created a menu which continues this tradition, bringing the best of China to the PDX Danwei.'
posts.rcmmnd: Best Chinese restaurant in every state (MSN website)

posts.name: Frank's Noodle House
posts.note: Frank's Noodle House is a homey, family-run joint with Chinese hand-pulled noodle mains and Korean BBQ plates, plus beer and wine. The thing to order is any of their hand-pulled noodle dishes. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: The Fried Onion
posts.note: The Fried Onion is a New York City street food. The Moussa is grilled onions, roasted red peppers, buffalo chicken, and pastrami sandwich. From their food stand at XOXO Festival, they served egg and cheese sandwiches with home-made basil pesto which I had for breakfast at least two days while at XOXO.

posts.name: Grilled Cheese Grill
posts.note: Grilled Cheese Grill is a hopping eatery housed in a converted school bus serving creative spins on the grilled cheese. The line was long and made other choices for my meals at XOXO Festival. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: HA VL
posts.note: HA and VL Vietnamese Noodle Soup is an unassuming Vietnamese eatery popular for its daily changing soups, plus banh mi (sandwiches). From the Bon Appetit website, 'This celebrated hole-in-the-wall pho shop, located in a nondescript strip mall off busy SE 82nd Avenue, was once a secret among in-the-know chefs. Well, the secret is out. The soup menu is sparse—just two regional Vietnamese soups per day—which may be why they usually sell out by noon. (Settling for a crusty banh mi or a meatball side isn’t a travesty, but the soup is the real draw here.) The ambrosial chicken curry noodle soup, fragrant of lemongrass and studded with tender carrots and potatoes, is comfort in a bowl. Feeling adventurous? Come on Monday for the bun rieu (pork vermicelli soup with shrimp cake, sliced pork meatloaf, tofu, and tomatoes) or on Thursday for the snail noodle soup.'

posts.name: Han Oak Restaurant
posts.note: Han Oak Restaurant is a minimal-chic Korean spot with upscale tasting menus with drink pairings, along with noodle and dumpling nights. From their website, 'Named after Korea's traditional homes, Han Oak is a non-traditional Korean-American family restaurant. We specialize in set-menu format dinners, a casual Dumpling and Noodle House, and private events.' From Eater Portland website, 'Peter Cho runs Han Oak — with his wife, Sun Young Park, and the two have accumulated a deafening amount of praise for it. However, Han Oak started small: just a few days open, then a few more. Now, it’s still not open more than four days per week.'
posts.rcmmnd: David Chang's Netflix show Ugly Delicious

posts.name: Hat Yai
posts.note: Hat Yai serves Thai plates and draft brews in this snug, rustic-chic counter serves with outdoor seating. Named after the Southern Thai city of Hat Yai near the Malaysian border, they passionately prepare famous Hat Yai Fried Chicken and favorite foods from Southern Thailand in the Vernon Neighborhood in Northeast Portland.

posts.name: Interurban
posts.note: Interurban is a bustling two-story saloon with retro hardwood decor serving craft cocktails and upscale bar snacks.

posts.name: Kachka
posts.note: Kachka is a lively spot for refined Russian fare and house-infused vodkas in kitschy surroundings. From their website, 'Kachka opened its doors in April of 2014 in Portland, Oregon. Kachka is considered by many to be the best Russian restaurant in the country, and is the only Portland restaurant to be included in America’s Essential Restaurants of 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018 by Eater, inducted into their restaurant “Hall of Fame.” Kachka was named one of GQ’s Most Outstanding Restaurants of 2015 and Bon Appétit’s Best New Restaurant nominees in 2015 and was a semifinalist for 2015’s James Beard Award for Best New Restaurant. In 2018, Kachka moved to a new, larger location in the Goat Blocks building on SE 11th Ave, and Kachinka was introduced to the original space.'

posts.name: Kenny and Zuke's Delicatessen
posts.note: Kenny and Zuke's Delicatessen is a buy spot serving a signature pastrami, bagels, and other deli fare in a roomy, light-filled space. You need to order the Jeremy which is mac and cheese with pastrami.

posts.name: Kim Jong Grillin’
posts.note: Kim Jong Grillin’ is possibly the best-named cart ever, with addictive Korean street food. After waiting in line, I ordered the Bibim Box which contains excellent bulgogi beef over fried rice, and it's topped with a fried egg.

posts.name: Lardo
posts.note: Lardo's a former food truck turned small, hip pork-centered sandwich shop, with draft beers and outdoor patio. They are known for their burgers and have great fries. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Laurelhurst Market
posts.note: Laurelhurst Market is a butcher shop/steakhouse providing unusual cuts, house-cured meats, and craft drinks in industrial digs.

posts.name: Le Pigeon
posts.note: Le Pigeon has a rotating menu of creative French-inspired fare served at communal tables or the bar in a snug room.

posts.name: Little Bird Bistro
posts.note: Little Bird Bistro is an eclectic, inventive French bistro fare served in a sexy spot with red banquettes and mezzanine level.

posts.name: Matt's BBQ
posts.note: Matt's BBQ is a little cart that makes the finest Texas ribs in the city, white-oak smoky with a ribbon of aching pink and tenderness beneath. Matt's chili-spiked hot links have a whiplash snap, and you could die of heartbreak between bites of the succulent beef brisket, whose beautifully thick bark now comes equipped with piquant salt-and-pepper bite.

posts.name: Matt's BBQ Tacos
posts.note: From Matt's BBQ Tacos website, 'All tortillas are pressed and cooked to order. Flour tortillas are made in house and contain lard. Corn tortillas are made with masa from Three Sisters Nixtamal and contain no animal or gluten products.'

posts.name: The Meadow
posts.note: At The Meadow, you can shop for many types of salt, along with chocolate, bitters, and even pink salt blocks. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Michael's Italian Beef and Sausage Co.
posts.note: Michael's Italian Beef and Sausage Company is a quick-serve destination for Chicago-style sandwiches, plus Italian sausage and other casual fare such as hot dogs.

posts.name: Nong’s Khao Man Gai
posts.note: Nong’s Khao Man Gai started as a food cart in Portland’s Southwest 10th and Alder Street pod, then graduated to two bricks and mortar restaurants, and now a bottled sauce available at select Portland retailers. This unique miniature empire revolves around one dish: Thai Chicken and Rice, a simple street food from Thailand. Nong’s Khao Man Gai has some of the best chicken and rice I have ever had and still think about it years later. At Nong’s Khao Man Gai, you can order a side of crispy chicken skin to add to your chicken and rice dish in those old school waxy sandwich sleeves people used decades ago. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Olympic Provisions
posts.note: Olympic Provisions has house-made charcuterie and European-style meals provided in an industrial space with a to-go counter. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Otto’s Sausage Kitchen and Meats
posts.note: Otto’s Sausage Kitchen and Meats is a longtime German deli with sidewalk picnic tables selling homemade sausages, hot dogs, and sandwiches. I found this place after watching a bicycle company video on YouTube, and the food looked great. From their website, 'Otto’s Sausage Kitchen was founded by Otto Eichentopf in 1922. Eichentopf was born in Germany and emigrated to the United States in 1911, at the age of 21. He opened his first business in Aberdeen, Washington, and married his longtime friend Selma soon after. Otto's Sausage Kitchen is a small, family-owned and operated meat market situated in southeast Portland's Woodstock neighborhood. Otto’s is not just about sausage. We have various deli meats, homemade salads, and hearty sandwiches that are all made at the store.'

posts.name: The Original Dinerant
posts.note: The Original Dinerant is an updated diner with meals dished out in a modern setting that's open late, with booths and a candlelit bar. You have to try the cheeseburger slider in donuts. Also, try the chicken thigh chicken waffles that have cheese and jalapeno inside them.

posts.name: OX Restaurant
posts.add1: 2225 NE Martin Luther King Jr Blvd
posts.note: OX Restaurant is a stylish eatery with a bar where Argentinean-inspired NW fare is cooked on a wood-fired grill. An XOXO Festival volunteer recommended I go here next time I'm in Portland after talking about my trip to Ned Ludd’s the day before.

posts.name: P's and Q's Market
posts.note: P's and Q's Market is an upscale store for gourmet groceries, organic produce, and dine-in or take-out that serves seasonal deli fare. I have heard you need to order the tomato gravy and biscuits or the polenta sandwich.

posts.name: PDX671
posts.note: PDX671 takes its name from Portland's airport code and the island of Guam's area code. PDX671 is a food cart that fuses seasonal ingredients of the Pacific Northwest with flavors and cooking techniques of Guam. You need to order yourself some Shrimp Fritters as an appetizer and then for your main meal the chicken and rice.

posts.name: Pine State Biscuits
posts.note: Pine State Biscuits is a casual eatery serving biscuits and gravy, biscuit sandwiches, and other Southern fare in a modern space. Order the Reggie Deluxe Chicken Biscuit sandwich which had fried chicken, bacon, gravy, and cheese with a fried egg on top. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Pine Street Market
posts.note: Pine Street Market is a bustling food hall with gourmet vendors, plus a mix of counter and communal seating. The list of restaurants inside Pine Street Market food hall is Bless Your Heart Burgers, Kim Jong Smokehouse, Kure, Marukin Ramen, Olympia Provisions Public House, Pollo Bravo, Checkerboard Pizza, Teote Outpost, and Wiz Bang Bar by Salt and Straw.

posts.name: Podnah's Pit Barbecue
posts.note: Podnah's Pit Barbecue is a smoked Texas-style barbecue and sides served in a simple, spacious restaurant with wood tables and bar. I've been told you need to get the sampler platter so you can try everything.

posts.name: Portland Japanese Garden
posts.note: Portland Japanese Garden has many styles of gardens showcased in serene 5.5-acre space with a waterfall, teahouse, and mountain view. It's a great getaway from the hustle and bustle of the city. You should find time to get there and relax but don't forget to do a tea tasting. I went with a friend a few years ago and had a great time talking and trying a variety of teas. NOTE: There is an admissions fee to the garden.

posts.name: Rose VL Deli
posts.note: Rose VL Deli serves Vietnamese fare, including banh mi and jumbo soups served in a bright and colorful space. From the Oregon Live website, 'When it opened in 2015 as a spin-off of nationally celebrated Southeast Portland soup shop Ha VL, Rose VL essentially replicated the original restaurant's menu, serving two distinct soups per day, six days a week. The biggest differences were the hours -- Rose VL opens and closes later than Ha VL -- and which soups were served on which days.'

posts.name: Roseline Coffee
posts.note: From the Roseline Coffee website, 'Consistently delicious coffee is what we strive for at Roseline. By creating meaningful relationships with our partners, importers, and coworkers, we curate the highest quality experience for our customers. At our core, our mission is simple: to share great coffee. We recognize that coffee is a seasonal fruit and that beans from different regions and climates should be treated differently. Finding an optimal roast profile for a given bean is often a labor-intensive and time-consuming process, but we believe that the only way to fully respect the intrinsic qualities of that bean is to tailor our roast to each lot. In so doing, we believe we are also respecting the hard work and attention to detail of those preceding us in the production chain. At Roseline Coffee, we will always source the highest quality and freshest ingredients.'

posts.name: Salt and Straw
posts.note: Salt and Straw loves exploring fun, interesting new ice cream flavors. All their flavors are great. It all depends on what you're in the mode to eat. My favorite is their Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons in a cup and a distant second is their Chocolate Gooey Brownie. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Sammich PDX
posts.note: Sammich PDX serve artisanal sandwiches using local ingredients and house-smoked meats in a laid-back space. Sammich PDX serves artisanal sandwiches using local ingredients and house-smoked meats in a laid-back space. From their website, 'We provide sandwiches made with the best ingredients and house-smoked meats. All our pastrami is brined and made in-house. We use regional produce when available and local bakeries for all our bread. Our goal is to provide the best quality sandwiches and to be known as the best pastrami in the nation. Pastrami Zombie is our food truck spin-off of our Sammich Chicago Italian eatery, located in Ashland, Oregon.' NOTE: They have a location in Ashland, OR.

posts.name: Scrumptious Crumpets
posts.note: Scrumptious Crumpets is a by-product of Tony Guerrero's selfishness to stuff his face (and now yours) full of crumpets. Come in and talk shop with him.

posts.name: Seastar Bakery
posts.note: Seastar Bakery uses fresh, whole grains grown by local farmers to create their delicious baked canvases for an array of seasonal toppings. They make toast in the hardest way possible – on the hearth of our wood-fired oven. And they get all their food inspiration from their families, real and adopted, across the planet.

posts.name: Swiss Hibiscus
posts.note: Swiss Hibiscus serves classic Swiss dishes and other European eats whipped up in a petite, low-key bistro with a patio.

posts.name: Tails and Trotters
posts.note: Tails and Trotters is a European-inspired market specializing in hazelnut-finished pork products, with a sandwich counter. You should order the three meat grinder which is made from in house-cured meats and/or the Porchetta sandwich.

posts.name: Tamale Boy
posts.note: Tamale Boy is a colorful counter-serve spot with a large patio and is known for its seasonal Mexican street fare. While attending XOXO Festival, I ordered their Oaxaqueño which is a traditional Oaxacan preparation. Creamy, twice cooked white corn masa filled with freshly prepared meats and vegetables. Steamed in a banana leaf mole nergo chicken cooked with traditional black mole. I also got their breakfast burrito. NOTE: They have two Portland brick and mortar locations.

posts.name: Tamale Boy - PDX Airport
posts.note: Tamale Boy has colorful counter-serve spot with a large patio is known for its seasonal Mexican street fare. Jaime Soltero Jr. started Tamale Boy as a catering company in 2008 called Mayahuel Catering. Tamale Boy has evolved into a food truck catering and restaurant business. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Tin Shed Garden Cafe
posts.note: Tin Shed Garden Cafe is a small, dog-friendly place specializing in American food, offering a covered patio and a canine menu. They offer wonderful vegetarian dishes.
